channel.title: Communism - could it work?
channel.description:
As we have seen throughout history, particularly in the past century, communism has flopped in any attempt to put it into a working government with humans as the pawns. This is rather unfortunate, because I do in fact believe that, with the right guidelines, a completely system of communism that relies completely on the balances of others could work in order to create a stabilized economy along with the removal of any existing central government and instead place that into individual powers that would be in complete alliance to manage individual areas of a nation.
The most common counter to communism is that human greed throws the system, and, by the end, a socialistic system is created where a single man is given all the power, the people are unhappy, and rebellion/uprisings become present. So tell me, Mopar, what are your opinions on this 'radical' (frowned upon) style of government? Do you think that it could work on more than paper, or maybe in smaller sects? Could a successful society overpower the human greed that is created by it? Or maybe it's something that's so ridiculous, you would never be in favor for the people should have an opinion and the majority of them aren't completely blowhards.
Discuss.

item.title: Communism - could it work?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

HcoJustin:

We actually tried a socialistic system the first year the pilgrims landed. Everyone was supposed to farm and do their own tasks and contribute to a general stockpile of goods. What happened? No one wanted to work and they nearly starved to death. The second year everyone was responsible for their own goods, and if you had any extra you could barter with it. We did much better with the barter system, which probably contributed to why we’ve kept it all these years

Well done, you’re wrong on just about everything.

The pilgrims (in Plymouth) weren’t socialist, while the pilgrims did agree to common ownership, it was always intended that they move to private ownership. But the farmers did work, and they weren’t lazy, you have to keep in mind that the pilgrims that settled in Plymouth came from all over England and had different dialects and different ways of doing things. Take a group of farmers from all parts of a country in colonial times and tell them that they have to work together, see how far that gets you. William Bradford reported that the pilgrims were unwilling to work because they didn’t want to work with each other, that they were confused because herpderp different accents and different backgrounds, single men didn’t want to farm to feed the wives of married men, the wives of married men didn’t want to wash the clothes of single men, husbands didn’t want to see their wives in the fields planting corn for the community, etc. But the communal ownership worked, and in 1621 the pilgrims had the first reported thanksgiving, a year after they had landed. If the communal ownership hadn’t have worked, they would have had their thanks giving after 1623 when they switched to private ownership, not before.

After the pilgrims switched to private ownership (which was the plan all along), the situation improved because there was no more squabbling between farmers that came from different backgrounds and didn’t get along with each other. Wives weren’t complaining about having to wash anyone but their husbands clothes, single farmers weren’t complaining about having to feed married men’s wives, etc.

Maybe you should read a loveing book instead of parroting the agendas of right wing media. The idea that pilgrims were socialist or even communists (HA!) comes almost exclusively from right wingers and conservatives who have a vested interest in discrediting anything left of capitalism. The myth of the socialist pilgrims was perpetuated by tea party members in the 1950s who would have used anything for propaganda against the communist Russians. You know, the 1950s, when America changed its national motto from “E pluribus unum” to “In God We Trust” to perpetuate the idea that Americans were superior to the godless Russian communists.
